results.title: Haunted Toaster Terrorizes Woman with Satanic Toast
results.description: A woman tries to prove her haunted toaster is possessed by the devil in this interview that aired on the Today Show in 1988.

meta_url.path: › home  › paranormal  › haunted toaster possessed by the devil

extra_snippets: 1988 television interview with a woman trying to demonstrate her demonic toaster that is possessed by the devil and makes Satanic toast.

She is sitting at her kitchen table in Boca Raton, Florida, with an inconspicuous white toaster in front of her. “What kind of voice did the devil have?” Richard asks her. “A very low voice I’d say sounded like Eli Wallach,” June says. Richard says, “Have you saved any of this satanic toast?” · Yes, of course June saved the evil toast. She holds up a piece of charred black toast with the words “Satan Lives” seemingly scratched into it.

She holds up a piece of charred black toast with the words “Satan Lives” seemingly scratched into it. Richard asks if the toaster is still possessed. They still have problems with it now and then, June confesses, and drops in a single slice of bread to demonstrate.

For this segment, Matson spoke with Richard Dominick, a reporter from The Sun (and later a producer for The Jerry Springer Show), who took him to meet a few of his subjects. There’s the guy who was rescued from the ice by his Howdy Doody ventriloquist dummy. The woman who spent years as a sex slave to extraterrestrial beings. And June O’brien with her haunted toaster.

results.title: Woman And Her Haunted Toaster Make For The 'Greatest Interview In Television History'?
results.description: The clip -- which was rediscovered ... to her haunted toaster. Talking to TV personality Richard Dominick, June O'Brien explains that her toaster talks to her in an evil voice -- one that she claims sounds a lot like Eli Wallach of "The Good, The Bad and the Ugly." O'Brien adds that the possessed appliance shoots fire and spits out bread stamped with the words "SATAN LIVES....
extra_snippets: The clip -- which was rediscovered by viral video-seeking Internet users over the weekend (see: Fark) -- captures a priceless "Today" show interview from 1984, in which a woman introduces the world to her haunted toaster. Talking to TV personality Richard Dominick, June O'Brien explains that her toaster talks to her in an evil voice -- one that she claims sounds a lot like Eli Wallach of "The Good, The Bad and the Ugly." O'Brien adds that the possessed appliance shoots fire and spits out bread stamped with the words "SATAN LIVES."
Woman And Her Haunted Toaster Make For The 'Greatest Interview In Television History'?

Talking to TV personality Richard Dominick, June O'Brien explains that her toaster talks to her in an evil voice -- one that she claims sounds a lot like Eli Wallach of "The Good, The Bad and the Ugly." O'Brien adds that the possessed appliance shoots fire and spits out bread stamped with the words "SATAN LIVES." ... If you've been sitting around for the past 27 years waiting to witness the greatest moment in television history, I've got some bad news: You missed it. Thankfully for us, the video was uploaded on YouTube in 2009, immortalizing the evil toaster's story for posterity.

results.title: I Don't Believe in Ghosts But I Want to Believe in the Haunted Toaster
results.description: Don’t you hate when you’re ... and your toaster burns the words “Satan lives” into your bread? June O’Brien, who appeared on the Today Show in May of 1984, wanted the world to believe. And even if you’re a skeptic, it’s hard to disagree with the fact that not only is this haunted toaster the ...
extra_snippets: Don’t you hate when you’re just trying to make breakfast and your toaster burns the words “Satan lives” into your bread? June O’Brien, who appeared on the Today Show in May of 1984, wanted the world to believe. And even if you’re a skeptic, it’s hard to disagree with the fact that not only is this haunted toaster the perfect spooky gadget, the woman who owned it is very convincing.

The Today Show segment first went viral in 2012 during the lead up to the Mayan Apocalypse scare (remember that bullshit?), but the video is a timeless artifact of gadget spookery. What most amazes me is that O’Brien never seems to break. By which I mean she really sells the idea that she believes this thing is haunted. ... I don’t believe in ghosts. But I really want to believe in the haunted toaster. Not because I think the devil actually inhabited the thing. But because this woman really, really seems to believe it. What do you think is going on here? Did some family member scrape “Satan lives?” into her toast?

Did some family member scrape “Satan lives?” into her toast? Did someone rig the thing with flames without her knowledge? Or was O’Brien in on the prank the entire time? I don’t need to believe that the toaster was haunted (it obviously wasn’t) but I really want to believe that she believed. It seems like such a more innocent “fake news” belief compared with the depressing shit we’re confronted with today. ... O’Brien tells the producers, one of which was Richard Dominick who would go on to work for the Jerry Springer Show, that the spooky toaster talks and sounds like Eli Wallach, a character actor from the 20th century who died in 2014.

Don’t you hate when you’re just trying to make breakfast and your toaster burns the words “Satan lives” into your bread? extra_snippets: Posted by u/[Deleted Account] - 2,254 votes and 163 comments

Somebody's been to a few sermons. Not too many, not too few, just enough of them to keep a sense of humor. ... I'll go as far at to say toasters don't exist. ... The greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't live in a toaster.

Because satan lives in my oven. He's a damn good cook btw. ... When all is said and done... it makes good toast. ... I mean have you ever dealt with a shitty toaster? It kinda ruins your mornings more than satan ever did. ... The road to hell is paved with good toast. ... Those flames, I theorise this is actually a portal to hell, and turning on the toaster there opened it. ... Had she placed blocks of obsidian in the correct rectangular pattern around the toaster it could have very well opened a portal.

The Bible says "the devil hath a pleasing face" so the toaster may be a toss-up, but at least we're safe from thinking she herself is the devil... ... Make sure you skip to 10:20 if you don't want to watch the whole thing. ... WHAT DO YOU WANT! ... Lady... all you have to do is throw it away. ... Gotta upvote a TPB reference. ... Didn't you watch it? The toast says "SATAN LIVES".

One of them featured a woman who claimed her toaster was POSSESSED and was writing the phrase "Satan Lives" on all her bread. But it was obvious that SHE was the one writing it, because the letters were actually CARVED IN. The best part is the end though, where she says she won't get rid of it because, quote, "When all is said and done, it makes good toast."

results.description: When breakfast is your beat, you find yourself researching terms like "haunted breakfast," "haunted food,"-and more specifically "haunted toaster." You ...
extra_snippets: When breakfast is your beat, you find yourself researching terms like “haunted breakfast,” “haunted food,”—and more specifically “haunted toaster.” You have made decisions that have led up to this moment in your career are you are grateful for them—especially when you indeed come upon one doozy of a haunted toaster story.

O’Brien believed her toaster was possessed by Satan. It burned and etched the words “SATAN LIVES” into a slice, shot flames into the air, and spoke to her in a voice she believed sounded like that of beloved character actor Eli Wallach. “Right there, where it says ‘put one slice’ we heard, ‘I am the Devil,’” O’Brien explained.

According to her, the toaster is possessed by Satan. · “Right here where it says ‘put one slice’ we heard ‘I am the devil,'” the Florida native says. · “What kind of voice did the devil ...
extra_snippets: In 1988, June O'Brien sat down with reporter Boyd Matson to talk about her haunted toaster. According to her, the toaster is possessed by Satan.  · “Right here where it says ‘put one slice’ we heard ‘I am the devil,'” the Florida native says.  · “What kind of voice did the devil have?” Matson asks her.

Apparently, at the time of the interview, the activity with the toaster had died down quite a bit. She still has problems with it, though, and even demonstrates how it won't pop a piece of toast down into the slot. Then, suddenly, the toaster briefly catches on fire.

extra_snippets: This classic example of WTF vintage television originally aired on The Today Show back in May, 1984. The “Richard” this lady keeps referring to off camera is Richard Dominick, a guy who later worked as a producer for Jerry Springer, a fact that will surprise absolutely no one who watches this amazing clip.
You’ll note the distinctive lack of skeptical follow-up when she presents the “Satan Lives” toast to the camera. I guess what happens afterwards vindicates that approach.

“SATAN LIVES” scratched into an old piece of terribly burnt toast is her first piece of evidence for ghost toast, and a veritable explosion of crumbs and other toaster stuff is the nail in the coffin. This fucking toaster is haunted! But the real zinger is at the end.

Yesterday, Gawker editor Neetzan Zimmerman unearthed “the greatest interview in television history” — a 1984 Today Show segment with a woman and her Satanic toaster. “SATAN LIVES” scratched into an old piece of terribly burnt toast is her first piece of evidence for ghost toast, and a veritable explosion of crumbs and other toaster stuff is the nail in the coffin.

results.title: Tales of the Weird
results.description: I may not share the lifestyle choices or even the same perception of reality with the characters I’ve met on my travels, but I will always appreciate their commitment to carving out little spaces of their own.
extra_snippets: Without a hint of embarrassment or irony, June of Boca Raton, Florida, explains that her toaster is possessed by the devil. How has she come to such a conclusion? “I heard a voice say, ‘I am the devil,’” she replies. To validate her claims for the Today show story I’m reporting, she produces supporting evidence—several slices of burnt toast with messages scraped into their blackened surfaces, allegedly by the devil. One has the number 666, another a pitchfork; a third says, “Satan Lives.”

One has the number 666, another a pitchfork; a third says, “Satan Lives.” · The chrome toaster is given a chance to prove its innocence or guilt while the camera rolls. As the woman struggles to insert a slice of bread, she warns, “It seems to be aware.” Within seconds, a flash and flames shoot from the coils.

In fact, she insists not to be from this planet. Now, I’ve occasionally suspected that certain acquaintances were not of this world, but never before has anyone stated as much so directly. Uriel, however, does not keep secrets, telling me (and anyone who will listen) that she has lived on 33 planets.

A woman in Atlanta swears to me, in front of her current husband, that she had lived with Elvis for three years; as proof she produces fuzzy pictures of a heavyset guy with hair dyed black. She is positive he was the real thing, because he always carried a briefcase full of pills.

results.title: Woman shares 'hidden compartment' in toaster and people never knew it existed - Mirror Online
results.description: A TikTok video showing how to clean a toaster has been viewed 2.2 million times as many people watching were left baffled to discover a 'hidden' feature of the appliance
extra_snippets: Before you rush angrily to the comments to rage that this is nothing new and is even written in black and white in the toaster manuals, it turns out that hundreds of people were today years old when they found out.
A cleaner's video has gone viral after she revealed the 'hidden compartment' in toasters making them easy to clean - and plenty of people have admitted they never knew it existed.

She says: "There are cleaning hacks going around the internet that are not really hacks at all, they make it harder. This week I was sent one. 'Clean your toaster with a hairdryer'. Just tip it in the bin."
But during the video, Kacie puts her hand under the toaster to pull out the tray which collects all the crumbs to empty it - and, strangely, it's blowing people's minds.
